qas.question: What is used in infrared photography to capture the near-infrared spectrum?
What devices are often equipped with infrared blockers?
What is the technique that involves imaging with terahertz radiation?
What is another name for terahertz radiation?
What is a notable recent development in T-ray imaging?
What does T-ray imaging use to capture the near-infrared spectrum?
What is a recent development in infrared photography?
What is another name for IR bright areas?
What device uses far-infrared or terahertz radiation?

plausible_answers.text: when taking pictures of subjects near IR-bright areas (such as near a lamp)

qas.question: How do infrared blockers wash out an image?

context: In infrared photography, <a0_0><b5_0>infrared filters<b5_0/><a0_0/> are used to capture the near-infrared spectrum. <a1_0><b8_0>Digital cameras<b8_0/><a1_0/> often use infrared blockers. Cheaper digital cameras and camera phones have less effective filters and can "see" intense near-infrared, appearing as a bright purple-white color. This is especially pronounced <b9_0>when taking pictures of subjects near IR-bright areas (such as near a lamp)<b9_0/>, where the resulting infrared interference can wash out the image. There is also a technique called <a2_0>'T-ray' imaging<a2_0/>, which is imaging using <a3_0><b7_0>far-infrared<b7_0/><a3_0/> or terahertz radiation. Lack of bright sources can make terahertz photography more challenging than most other infrared imaging techniques. Recently T-ray imaging has been of considerable interest due to a number of new developments such as <a4_0><b6_0>terahertz time-domain spectroscopy<a4_0/>.
